text.headline:
Vortex
2005 - 2015
text.text: Vortex is a little story of success. Today, 10 years after its foundation by two PhD in Atmospheric Physics and a self-taught IT expert, the company has offices in 3 continents and serves users from 149 countries

media.caption: Pep Moreno installing a met. mast during a measurement campaign in Northern Spain. Early 90’s

text.headline: A young company made up of old experts
text.text: Vortex was born in Barcelona on 19 September 2005 but its team’s background is much older. The accumulated experience in the wind industry of its members goes back 25 years

media.caption: David Saez at first Vortex computer cluster. Early 2006

text.headline: Just a simple, powerful idea
text.text: The foundational approach of the Vortex service was simple: remote atmospheric modeling launched on-line. With the aim to 'bring the power of a supercomputer to your fingerprints' in mind, our first computer cluster was set up in 2006

media.caption: Professor Josep Calbó returning from the University of Girona with his, at that time 2 years old, daughter. Late 2006

text.headline: Research that faces the real world
text.text: We love research: half of Vortex employees hold a PhD and we keep active links with several research institutes since our first collaboration with the University of Girona in 2006. However, the continuos feedback from our users makes us always keep research tight to real world 'imperfections'

media.caption: One of the first drafts of Vortex Interface. Early 2007

text.headline:
Complex modeling at
one-click distance
text.text: From its first sketches in 2007, the philosophy of Vortex Interface was to reduce the complexity of the atmospherice modeling down to intuitive user website actions. Since the beginning, user manuals and courses were strictly forbiden

media.caption: Pau Casso at Longs Peak (Colorado, US) after attending the 9th WRF Users' Workshop in Boulder, CO. July 2008

text.headline: A cloud (service) with solid foundations
text.text: Vortex is not a large company but we are not at all alone. Since our first compilation of the WRF model in 2006, our core technology relies on a collaborative code developed through the effort of a community of over 23,000 registered users

media.caption: Gil Lizcano at Vortex office in Brussels, Belgium. Early 2009

text.headline: Natural born glocal
text.text: Wind does not understand about borders, so does not Vortex team. By opening first satellite office in Brussels in 2009, vortex strengthens its presence in Europe

text.headline: The Eyjafjallajökull eruption
text.text: The eruption of a Icelandic volcano on 14 April 2010 affected the economic, political and cultural activities in Europe and across the world. There was extensive air travel disruption caused by the closure of airspace over many countries affecting the travel arrangements of hundreds of thousands of people in Europe and elsewhere (Wikipedia)

media.caption: German Delgado receiving the 'Eyjafjallajökul' award from Bruce Douglas (EWEA's COO) during the EWEC conference dinner in Warsaw. May 2010

text.headline: Caravan to the Far East
text.text: EWEC 2010 was going to be our first EWEA annual event but the eruption of the Eyjafjallajökul did not allow us (and many others) to fly to Warsaw. No thinking twice, we drove up there in a motorhome. 2400 km traveled to Poland made us worthy of the prize (a bottle of vodka) to the participants driving from further
